# Task

Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".



# Data

clean_column("My Column")

Here is a Julia function that accomplishes this task:

```julia
function clean_column(col)
    # lowercase the column name and replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    return replace(lowercase(col), r"[ -]+" => "_")
end
```
You can then call `clean_column` function with a string as an argument to clean it:
```julia
println(clean_column("My Column"))  # prints "my_column"
```

This function works by first lowercasing the input column name (which converts all characters to their lowercase equivalent, if they exist), and then replacing any sequences of one or more spaces or hyphens with a single underscore using `replace(lowercase(col), r"[ -]+" => "_")`. The regular expression `[ -]+` matches one or more spaces or hyphens.
